message: Actually, I prefer using Func for delayed scheduling. Thanks for reminding me of that!

Thanks for the article, Stephen. I agree, task constructors are useful (only?) for delayed task scheduling.   
I am using task constructor as a workaround for some problems with task scheduling in my BOOST ASIO .Net.  

[https://bitbucket.org/renestein/rstein.async/src/06551e00773c6adbf807c4b4e6b685adde858cc4?at=master](https://bitbucket.org/renestein/rstein.async/src/06551e00773c6adbf807c4b4e6b685adde858cc4?at=master)

​A great article, thanks. I once answered a question where I used a Task constructor to simulate a promise-style task: [http://stackoverflow.com/q/22704575/1768303](http://stackoverflow.com/q/22704575/1768303). It was admittedly contrived but still interesting.
That code doesn't use the task constructor. Code using the task constructor looks like "Task<string> getStringTask = new Task<string>();".
Ah sorry, brain fade on my part, thanks.
